review.title: Learning Multi-target Tracking with Quadratic Object Interactions
review.abstract: We describe a model for multi-target tracking based on associating collections of candidate detections across frames of a video. In order to model pairwise interactions between different tracks, such as suppression of overlapping tracks and contextual cues about co-occurence of different objects, we augment a standard min-cost flow objective with quadratic terms between detection variables. We learn the parameters of this model using structured prediction and a loss function which approximates the multi-target tracking accuracy. We evaluate two different approaches to finding an optimal set of tracks under model objective based on an LP relaxation and a novel greedy extension to dynamic programming that handles pairwise interactions. We find the greedy algorithm achieves equivalent performance to the LP relaxation while being 2-7x faster than a commercial solver. The resulting model with learned parameters outperforms existing methods across several categories on the KITTI tracking benchmark.

metadata.title: Learning Multi-target Tracking with Quadratic Object Interactions

sections.heading: 2. Model
sections.text: We begin by formulating multi-target tracking and data association as a minimum-cost-flow network problem similar to that of [27], where individual tracks are described by a first-order Markov model whose state space is spatio-temporal positions in videos. This framework includes a state transition probability that generates transitional features in successive images, and an observation probability that generates appearance characteristics for objects and background.

sections.heading: 2.1.1 Track interdependence
sections.text: The aforementioned model assumes that tracks are independent of each other, which is not always the case in practice. An essential contribution of our work is that pairs of track-to-track relationships can be integrated into the model to improve tracking performance. To enable interactions between multiple objects, we add a pair of cost terms called qij and qji to jointly activate a pair of flows fi and fj, which corresponds to the detections at the sites xi = (li, σi, ti) and xj = (lj, σj, tj). An intuitive example of qij and qji would be a penalty for overlapping points or a push for adjacent objects. We only consider pairs of interactions between sites in the same video image, which we call EC = {Javij: ti = tj} Java Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java + Java +

sections.heading: 3. Inference
sections.text: These follow-up routines are used both to predict a set of test time tracks and to optimize parameters during learning (see Section 5). As mentioned in the previous section, for the traditional Mincost Network Flow problem defined in Equation 2, there are various efficient solvers that examine its total uniformity to find the global optimum. We use MOSEK's built-in Network Simplex Solver in our experiments, as other alternative algorithms provide exactly the same solution. In contrast, finding the global minimum of IQP problem 4 is due to the square terms NP-hard [26]. We evaluate two different schemes to find high-quality approximate solutions. The first is a standard approach to introduce auxiliary variables and loosen the integral constraints of the IQP problem to yield a linear program (LP) that falls short of the original goal.

sections.heading: 3.1. LP Relaxation and Rounding
sections.text: If we loosen the holistic constraints and deform the costs as necessary to solve the objective problem, then the global optimum of 4 can be found in polynomial time. For example, one could use the Frank Wolfe algorithm to optimize relaxed convexed QP while pursuing good holistic solutions at the same time. [13] However, for real-world tracking over long videos, relaxed QP is still quite expensive. Instead, we follow the approach proposed by Chari et al. [6] The reformulation of IQP as an equivalent ILP problem by replacing the quadratic terms fifj with a set of auxiliary variables uij.

sections.heading: 3.2. Greedy Sequential Search
sections.text: We will now describe a simple greedy algorithm inspired by the combination of dynamic programming and nonmaximum suppression proposed in [20]. We will perform a series of rounds of dynamic programming to find the shortest path between source and sink nodes. In each round, once we have identified a track, we will update the (simple) costs associated with all detections to include the effects of the paired square interaction term of the newly activated track (e.g., suppression of overlapping detections, increasing the results of frequently occurring objects), analogous to greedy algorithms for maximum weight independent sentences where the elements are paths through the network. Algorithm 1 DP with pairwise cost update 1: Input: A directs-cyclic graph G with edge weights ci, cij 2: initialize T: 1: repeat 4: path-to-end (finto-end) p).

sections.heading: 4. Tracking Features and Potentials
sections.text: To learn the traceability potentials (c and q), we parameterise the flow cost object by a vector of weights w and a series of characteristics that depend on the characteristics extracted from the video, the spatio-temporal relationship between the candidates and the candidates related to it. The vector components of the weight and feature vector are given by: w = wS wt ws wa wE (X, f) s, where the negative sign is a useful convention to turn the minimization problem into a maximization. The vector components of the weight and feature vector are given by: w = wS wt ws wa wE (X, f) s, if the negative sign is a useful convention to turn the minimization problem into a maximization.

sections.heading: 5. Learning
sections.text: We formulate parameter learning of tracking models as a structured prediction problem. Suppose we have N training videos (Xn, fn), X · F, n = 1,..., N. Given basic tracks in training videos specified by flow variables fn, we learn discriminatory tracking model parameters w using a structured SVM with margin recalculation: w * = argmin w, n = 01 2 + C * n (8) s.t., n *, f *, < w, 4B (Xn, fn, f *) > ≥ L (fn, f *) − nwhere4B (Xn, fn, f *) = "(Xn, fn *)." These are the characteristics extracted from the n training video. L (fn, f *) is a loss function that does not include any difference between the transferred label and the unspecified label * so that the costs for tracking are not high in the label.

sections.heading: 5.1. Cutting plane optimization
sections.text: We optimize the structured SVM target in 8 using a standard intersection method [12], in which the exponential number of constraints (one for each possible flow direction f) is approximated by a much smaller number of terms. Given a current estimate of w, we can apply these constraints to the optimization problem and solve it for an updated flow direction. This procedure will continue until no additional constraints are added to the problem. In our implementation, we add a single linear constraint that contains a sum of constraints on the optimization problem.

sections.heading: 6. Experimental results
sections.text: This year, it is more than ever before in the history of the country in which it is a country, in which it is a country, in which it is a country, in which it is a country.

sections.heading: 7. Summary
sections.text: We have added pairs of costs to the well-studied network flow tracking model and proposed an end-to-end framework that collectively optimizes the parameters for such a model. We have extensively evaluated a traditional relaxation-based LP method and a novel, greedy dynamic programming process for conclusions about the extended network, both of which achieve state-of-the-art performance, while our greedy DP algorithm is 2-7x faster than a commercial LP solver.

sections.heading: 8. Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was supported by NSF DBI-1053036, IIS1253538 and a Google Research Award.

sections.heading: 9. Appendix: Multi-Pass Dynamic Programming to Approximate Successive Shortest
sections.text: PathNow we describe two algorithms proposed by [20] for dynamic programming (DP) that approximate successive algorithms for the shortest path (SSP). sections.heading: 9.1. One-pass DP
sections.text: We designate costs (i) as the cost of the shortest path from source node to node i, link (i) as the precursor of i on this shortest path, and birth node (i) as the first recognition node on this shortest path. We initialize costs (i) = ci + csi, link (i) = ∅ and birth node (i) = i for all i-V. To find the shortest path on the initial DAG G, we can switch from the first to the last frame, calculation costs (i) as: costs (i) = ci + min (i), and birth node (i) = i for all i-V. The cost of this process would be (i) costs that we all reach from this way.

sections.heading: 9.2. Two-pass DP
sections.text: 2-pass DP works very similar to consecutive shortest path, the only difference is that instead of using Dijkstra's Forward DP algorithm, we use two passes of dynamic programming to approximate the shortest path on the remaining graph Gr (f). We refer to Vforward as a set of forward-facing nodes in the current residual graph and VReverse as a set of backward-facing nodes in the current residual graph, we describe an iteration of 2-pass DP as down: 1. Ignore all backward-facing edges (including reverse detection edges) and perform a pass forward DP (from the first frame to the last frame) on all nodes. For each node i, there will be a path (i) that stores a mininum-cost source to i-path, where cost (i) is the total cost of that path. 2. Let's use cost (i) of step 1 as initial values and perform a pass backwards (from the last frame to the first frame).

sections.heading: 10. Appendix: Incorporating Quadratic Interactions in Multi-pass DP
sections.text: Recall the problem of the extended network flow with square costs (Eqn. 4): min f-i-csif s i + ∑ ij-E cijfij + ∑ ij-EC qijfifj + ∑ i ctif t is.t. fsi + ∑ j fji = fi = f t i + ∑ j fijfsi, f t i, fi, fij-i {0, 1} Where EC = {ij: ti = tj} is written, we propose two new variants of the DP algorithm that can roughly minimize Goal 4. They are also divided into 1-Pass DP and 2-Pass DP. As we have already described 1-Pass DP with pair interactions in the paper, we will focus here on 2-Pass DP with pair interactions.

sections.heading: 10.1. Two-pass DP with quadratic interactions
sections.text: A workable solution f on the network corresponds to a RestgraphGr (f). We could apply the steps described in Section 9.2 to find an approximately shortest path, which can consist of both forward-facing nodes and backward-facing nodes that correspond to uninstanced discoveries (but are instanced after this iteration) and already-instanced discoveries (but are not instanced after this iteration). We could then update the (unary) costs of other nodes by adding or subtracting the pairwise costs imposed by turning selected nodes on or off the path. In addition, at step 3 of the 2-pass DP, we could also consider the pairwise costs of the current node imposed by previously selected nodes on the same path. The whole process is described as an algorithm 2.Notice that we cyclize to simplify our notation, we can consider temporary residual graphics at the beginning of each iteration and algorithm 2-Cirwise A: Directed to Direcost-1.

sections.heading: 10.2. Approximation Quality of Two-pass DP
sections.text: We found that 2-Pass-DP is often cheaper than 1-Pass-DP, but still not as good as LP + rounding. It also runs significantly slower, even slower, than LP + rounding on long sequences. On a 1059 frame video with 3 categories of objects, 2-Pass-DP takes about 6 minutes to complete, while 1-Pass-DP is completed within 1 minute and LP + rounding is completed within 4 minutes. The result of cross-validation with 2-Pass-DP is a MOTA of 60.4%, which is equivalent to the relaxation of 1-Pass-DP and LP. We observed that most of the runtime for 2-Pass-DP is on the second forward pass, which includes tracing for each forward node to avoid cyclic paths.

In Section 5 we describe an approach to joint learning of model parameters in order to maximize tracking performance on a training data set using techniques for structured prediction [22].

Structured prediction has been applied in tracking to learning inter-frame affinity metrics [14] and association [18] as well as a variety of other learning tasks such as fitting CRF parameters for segmentation [21] and word alignment for machine translation [15].

We begin by formulating multi-target tracking and data association as a min-cost flow network problem equivalent to that of [27], where individual tracks are described by a first-order Markov Model whose state space is spatialtemporal locations in videos.
This ILP is a well studied problem known as minimum-cost network flow [1].

The constraints satisfy the total unimodularity property and thus can be solved exactly using any LP solver or via various efficient specialized solvers, including network simplex, successive shortest path and push-relabel with bisectional search [27].

To mimic the temporal NMS described in [20] we add one additional relation, strictly overlap, which is defined as the intersection of two boxes over the area of the first box; we set the corresponding feature to 1 if this ratio is greater than 0.

metadata.abstractText: We describe a model for multi-target tracking based on associating collections of candidate detections across frames of a video. In order to model pairwise interactions between different tracks, such as suppression of overlapping tracks and contextual cues about co-occurence of different objects, we augment a standard min-cost flow objective with quadratic terms between detection variables. We learn the parameters of this model using structured prediction and a loss function which approximates the multi-target tracking accuracy. We evaluate two different approaches to finding an optimal set of tracks under model objective based on an LP relaxation and a novel greedy extension to dynamic programming that handles pairwise interactions. We find the greedy algorithm achieves equivalent performance to the LP relaxation while being 2-7x faster than a commercial solver. The resulting model with learned parameters outperforms existing methods across several categories on the KITTI tracking benchmark.
